doc.title: Minerals Therapeutics Inc. (MLYS): Our thesis Validated: BAX-HTN Underperformed and KARDIA-3 Underwhelmed Vs. Launch-HTN
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-30/Mineralys Therapeutics Inc. MLYS Our Thesis Validated BAX-HTN Underperformed and KARDIA-3 Underwhelmed Vs. Launch-HTN Mi_2025-08-30

passages.text: On Saturday 8/30, MLYS's competitor AZN presented results from baxdrostat's pivotal Ph. 3 BaxHTN study in \(3L+\) uHTN/HTN patients on two background anti- hypertensive therapies (including one diuretic), which were simultaneously published in NEJM. Although BaxHTN met its primary endpoint for 1- 2 mg QD doses, its placebo- adjusted SBP reduction and confirmed hyperkalemia \(>6.0\) mmol/L were numerically worse than lourndrostat's Launch- HTN results (Exhibit 1). After 12 weeks, baxdrostat's placebo- adjusted SBP reductions were 9.8 mmHg (15.7 mmHg absolute) for 2 mg QD and 8.7 mmHg (14.5 mmHg absolute) for 1 mg QD. By comparison, recall that lourndrostat showed an impressive 11.7 mmHg placebo- adjusted SBP reduction (19.0 mmHg absolute) at week 12 for the 50 mg dose in Launch- HTN. Baxdrostat's incidence of confirmed hyperkalemia \(>6.0\) mmol/L was \(1.1\%\) for 1- 2 mg doses and higher than lourndrostat's \(0.6\%\) incidence in Launch- HTN. While confirmed measurements were not reported for other thresholds, baxdrostat's single measurement of hyperkalemia for \(K+ > 5.5\) and \(>6.0\) mmol/L for 1- 2 mg QD doses were \(- 6 - 11\%\) and \(- 2 - 3\%\) , respectively (vs. \(8.2\%\) \(>5.5\) mmol/L and \(1.1\%\) \(>6.0\) mmol/L for lourndrostat 50 mg QD). Baxdrostat's \(K+ > 6.5\) mmol/L was \(1.9\%\) for 1 mg and \(0.4\%\) for 2 mg. Both were higher than lourndrostat's \(0.2\%\) incidence (0% based on repeat measure) for 50 mg QD. Overall, we believe BaxHTN's results underperformed and Launch- HTN's \(\sim 2\) mmHg higher reduction is considered clinically meaningful according to KOLs we consulted. The results were also consistent with our strong conviction that Launch- HTN's efficacy was a high bar and difficult to beat/match. While we acknowledge typical limitations in cross- trial comparisons, we believe lourndrostat's numerically/meaningfully greater SBP reduction with favorable safety supports a best- in- class profile and could give MLYS commercial/promotional advantages. We will further discuss BaxHTN's implications in our dinner NDR with MLYS mgmt + its KOL (Dr. Manish Saxena) on Sunday, 8/31.

MLYS can promote Launch- HTN's 12- week results despite its primary endpoint being at week 6- since its full clinical results will be reflected in the label if approved. Although BaxHTN's week 6 results were not reported, we estimated its placebo- adjusted SBP reductions were \(\sim 76 - 79\) mmHg at week 4 and \(\sim 8.0 - 8.4\) mmHg at week 8 for 1- 2 mg QD doses, which were numerically lower than lourndrostat's \(9.1\) mmHg at week 6.

Baxdrostat NDA by YE25 could challenge lorundrostat's first- in- class potential. Per Endpoints news, AZN plans to submit baxdrostat's NDA by YE25, which would come before lorundrostat's expected NDA filing since MLYS has not yet guided (we expect early 2026). However, this timeline was not mentioned in AZN's PR. AZN confirmed it will share results from its Ph. 3 Bax24 study in 2H25, although we view the read- through from this study as less relevant and not comparable to MLYS's studies.

Zilebesiran's Ph. 2 KARDIA- 3 results in 3L+ HTN underwhelmed but consistent with our expectations. Placebo- adjusted SBP reduction for zilebesiran \(300mg\) Q6M was only slightly statistically significant at 3 months (- 5.0 mmHg; \(\mathsf{p} = 0.0431\) ). However, the higher \(600mg\) Q6M dose (- 3.3 mmHg; \(\mathsf{p} = 0.1830\) ) failed to meet statistical significance. Overall, these results are not surprising since - 83- 84% of patients were already on background ACEi/ARB therapy where zilebesiran's mechanism was redundant in targeting the RAAS pathway. A post- hoc analysis of patients on diuretics w/ baseline SBP \(>140mmHg\) revealed higher placebo- adjusted SBP reduction of 9.2 mmHg at 3 months. However, given KARDIA- 3's underwhelming results and zilebesiran's overlapping mechanism, we continue to struggle in finding an apparent place for zilebesiran in the treatment algorithm since ACEi/ARBs are highly preferred generics in prescribers' armamentarium and payers' formularies. In our view, replacing ACEi/ARB in 1L or as a backbone therapy in subsequent lines is not realistic. Adding zilebesiran on ACEi/ARB seems redundant.

Valuation: Our \(32, 12\) - month price target for MLYS is based on: 1) an \(85\%\) weighting to a DCF analysis that assumes a WACC of \(17\%\) and a terminal growth rate (TGR) of \(0\%\) , which indicates an intrinsic value of \(31, and 2) a\) 15% weighting to a theoretical M&A valuation that assumes an 11x sales multiple applied to our risk- adjusted 2030E sales.

Risks: Key downside risks include lower than expected commercial opportunity for lorundrostat; safety concerns, including hyperkalemia; inability to show differentiated efficacy vs. competitors' pivotal studies; pipeline risks associated with being a single- asset company; liquidity/funding difficulties in developing lorundrostat; negative feedback/rejection of future regulatory submissions in the US/EU; inability to secure an established commercial partner; pricing and reimbursement challenges.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
